utterances: We begin this hour with the latest on the Asiana Airlines flight from Seoul, South Korea, which crash landed at San Francisco International Airport earlier today.
NPR's Richard Gonzales joins us now from San Francisco with the latest.
Richard, let's start with what we've heard about casualties.
What's being reported?
Well, Rebecca, at this stage, there's no official word about casualties.
We're waiting a news conference that's supposed to happen very soon, and we're going to hear the official word from San Francisco Mayor Ed Lee, but he's not yet arrived.
Here's what we do know: that at least 75 people were injured; 10 are critical at San Francisco General Hospital.
Of those 10, eight are adults and two are children.
Another five passengers are reported to be en route to San Francisco General.
These are very preliminary reports.
More details will emerge as we learn more.
And as I mentioned, a news conference with more details is expected to happen any moment now.
So, Richard, what happened here?
What do we know about how this plane crashed while it was landing in San Francisco?
Here's what we know.
Asiana flight 214 arriving from Seoul, South Korea - it was a Boeing 777 - approached the runway here in San Francisco.
According to witnesses - and there were many witnesses - they say that the plane's approach just did not look right.
The plane came in at an awkward angle.
And apparently, it just came up short, and it wound up hitting a seawall right next to the runway here in San Francisco.
The tail section landed first on impact and basically just disintegrated.
And then the plane, according to witnesses, basically bounced down the runway.
It was pretty dramatic event for people who saw that.
Again, there were 291 people on that plane.
And according to these preliminary reports, most of them walked away from it.
Richard, what else do you know about the response to the crash?
Well, immediately, there were emergency response vehicles surrounding the vehicle.
There was a great deal of smoke - first black smoke, people say, and white smoke and then black smoke again.
There are conflicting reports about whether there was an actual fire.
But all of the emergency crew were on the scene immediately.
A Medevac chopper was brought in to take some people to local Bay Area hospitals.
The hospitals are spread out over three counties.
As I say, many passengers were able to get off the plane using the emergency evacuation chutes and were able to walk away from the crash.
(Unintelligible) flights into San Francisco International are delayed or canceled.
Flights that were destined for San Francisco are now being diverted to Oakland...
Now, Richard, as with most news events these days, the social media world has been very active on the story.
And, of course, we approach these reports with caution.
But what have you seen out there in the Twittersphere, on Facebook?
You know, it's (unintelligible) people who are on the flight were able to take pictures and tweet them and send out some of the video almost immediately.
We have reports about one (unintelligible) executive of Samsung.
He apparently got off the flight, was walking away, turned around and took a picture, saying, you know, I've just - I got - my plane just crashed.
And you could see that the - his pictures being printed everywhere.
There was another local man who reported that his wife sent him a video of the aftermath.
At that time, he reported that most people appeared to have survived the crash.
That appears to be the case.
But again, I repeat these are very preliminary reports.
That's NPR's Richard Gonzales.
Boeing 777 has crashed on landing at San Francisco International Airport.
Reports are still preliminary, but area hospitals say as many as 75 people are injured; some in critical condition.
We will provide updates as we get them.
If your holiday budget is already stretched, you are not going to like your next visit to the gas station.
The national average for regular unleaded gasoline has risen to $2.98.
That is the highest price ever recorded in any December.
[POST-BROADCAST CORRECTION: That is the highest gas price ever recorded during the days before Christmas, when many people do most of their holiday shopping.
It is worth noting that it is not the highest price ever paid in December for gas.
That price was $3.00/gallon on December 27, 2007.]
It is much more common for gas to soar around the Fourth of July.
NPR's Sonari Glinton looks at what current gas prices may mean for holiday shoppers.
The price of gas is high and may be getting higher.
We have never within the United States have ever paid $3 a gallon at Christmas time.
Troy Green is a spokesman for AAA, the auto club.
I could take you to a map real quick.
In his office, Green shows me a map of the country and where prices are spiking.
So you'll see that, for example, California, basically the Pacific Coast - some of the most expensive gasoline can be found in that part of the country, as well as in the Northeast.
With prices in those areas well above the $3 mark, that brings the national average to $2.98.
Now, typically December and January are when the price of gas bottoms out.
Green says he's worried the current price spike will mean even more expensive gasoline come summer.
Right now the recovery, it's still in its beginning stages.
We still don't know what $3 a gallon gasoline will mean for the economic recovery coming up in the future.
But wait.
Before we jump ahead to summer, what do these high gas prices mean for holiday shoppers?
She's in a secondary role to the doctors often, as nurses can be.
Let's listen to a scene where she shows that she's not just going to accept everything that comes along.
(Soundbite of television program, ""Nurse Jackie"")
(As Nurse Jackie) Dr. Cooper?
(As Dr. Fitch Cooper) Coop.
Call me Coop.
(As Nurse Jackie) Dr. Cooper.
(As Dr. Cooper) Nurse Jackie.
So, what's up?
What can I do for you?
(As Nurse Jackie) What you can do for me is this.
You can stay the (BEEP) out of my way.
That's what you can do to me.
(As Dr. Cooper) You need to use the sink?
(As Nurse Jackie) No. What I need is for you to know that I know you.
I have seen hundreds of you blow through these doors.
You've graduated, what, the top 10, top five percent of your class?
Right?
Test scores through the roof, but a total (BEEP) retard when it comes to actual patients?
I know you.
I just had to sit there and look that kid's mother in the eye and tell her that we did everything we could you dumb (BEEP).
That was my patient.
I told you he was slipping, and he was.
When I tell you to order a scan, you order a (BEEP) scan because if you don't do it, I'll just go to the next doctor and the next doctor after that.
In the meantime, that kid died, and it is all on you.
This is a really strong woman.
And while I don't know you personally, I get the feeling that was important to you personally.
Well, I think the situation with Jackie would be similar no matter what she did for a living.

I think she's passionate and smart, and wherever she ended up in her life, she would end up being probably the best at doing it, and she sticks to it for a long time so that she can be the best at doing it.
I think she's been a nurse forever and ever.
So, I think had that doctor been a woman, her reaction would have been the same.
I think she doesn't want anyone to get in the way of her getting done what needs to get done because she knows how it needs to get done.
So, I respect that in any person, a man or a woman or a kid, for heaven's sake.
You know, if there's someone who may be, status-wise in a higher place, it's irrelevant because the work that needs to get done is of primary importance.
You know, the other thing that really comes through that I thought accurate is the incredible weariness that people have undergoing that, the kind of almost out-of-body tiredness.
And you let the character's weariness really show.
And I just had to ask, did you have any qualms about that, letting the frownies appear, letting the lines begin to show?
No, you know, I'm - I've spent a lot of years getting those frown lines, you know, and I've enjoyed every second of it, and I'm very attached to myself.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Let me rephrase that.
I'm very attached to my face.
You know, I mean, we've been together a long time.
I wouldn't want to change anything about it.
And I have no desire to portray people looking a way that they don't look naturally.
I just don't understand that impulse.
So, I've also never gotten anything in my life because of the way I look, and I've never not gotten anything important to me because of the way that I look.
So, it's irrelevant to me.
You know, I am who I am, and I'm not being holier than thou about it.
I genuinely feel that way.
Edie Falco, what is it like to have an entire show centered on you?
This is a half-hour show, as opposed to an hour, but it is - you know, you are front, center and the theme line.
I like it.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Very fancy.
No, I actually do like it, though.
I'm a very hard worker.
And I - you know, it got embarrassing on ""Sopranos"" because half the time I wanted to be there even if I wasn't working just because I like to be around what's going on.
I like to be involved in my work, you know, in lots of aspects of it.
I felt sad that I missed all kinds of stuff on ""Sopranos"" because I wasn't working that day.
And here, I'm working.
I'm there all the time.
I'm there from, you know, when people are saying hello in the morning until they're, you know, wearily walking out the door 13 hours later.
I just love it.
I really have never felt so intrinsically connected to the action, you know, it suits me.
Edie Falco, she joined us from our New York bureau.
Nurse Jackie"" airs Monday, June 8 on Showtime.
It has been a real pleasure.
Thank you, thank you.
(Soundbite of music)
